docs.lead_paragraph: In a small study, researchers have found that the caffeine equivalent to two cups of coffee appears to reduce significantly the body's ability to increase blood flow to the heart in response to exercise. The effect was especially strong when volunteers exercised while breathing air that simulated the oxygen levels at high altitudes.

headline.main: Advice on Racing to a Starbucks in Denver

docs.abstract: Dr Philipp Kaufmann, University Hospital, Zurich, cardiology professor, leads study that finds caffeine taken before exercise at high altitude can reduce blood flow to heart during activity; research, which is published in Journal of American College of Cardiology, suggests individuals with coronary artery problems may want to limit caffeine before doing exercise at high altitudes (M)
docs.snippet: The caffeine in two cups of coffee can reduce the body's ability to increase blood flow to the heart in response to exercise.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: JOURNAL OF AMERICAN COLLEGE OF CARDIOLOGY

docs.lead_paragraph: Among the many temptations of the digital age, photo-manipulation has proved particularly troublesome for science, and scientific journals are beginning to respond. Some journal editors are considering adopting a test, in use at The Journal of Cell Biology, that could have caught the concocted images of the human embryonic stem cells made by Dr. Hwang Woo Suk.

headline.main: It May Look Authentic; Here's How to Tell It Isn't

docs.abstract: Use of digital images within scientific research papers has brought about cases of photo manipulation that at best make image clearer and at worst falsify results; Micheal Rossner and Ira Mellman, editors of Journal of Cell Biology, describe their efforts to root out images that distort truth, using same technology involved in altering images; journal prohibits changing any one part of image, but allows changes that affect all parts equally, such as brightening entire image, but not brightening one section of photo; suggests that fraudulent manipulations are infrequent, but do exist; examples of digital manipulation described; photos; graph (L)
docs.snippet: Photo-manipulation has proved particularly troublesome for science. One journal is showing the way in a new offensive against fraud.

docs.lead_paragraph: A large study has found that heart attack victims are less likely to die in hospitals where angioplasty is the usual emergency treatment rather than clot-destroying drugs. Examining the records of 463 hospitals, researchers found that the group of hospitals that performed angioplasty the most often had a 36 percent lower risk of in-hospital death compared with the group of hospitals that used it least.

headline.main: For Heart Treatment, Nod Goes to Angioplasty

docs.abstract: Dr Harlan M Krumholz, Yale University medical professor, leads study on use of angioplasty as emergency heart attack treatment; research, which is published in Journal Circulation, suggests significantly lower death rates among patients treated with angioplasty than those treated with clot-destroying drugs; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Heart attack victims are less likely to die in hospitals where angioplasty is the usual emergency treatment rather than clot-destroying drugs.

docs.lead_paragraph: Longtime exposure to loud noise may increase the risk of developing a benign nerve tumor called an acoustic neuroma, Swedish research suggests. The tumor, which grows inside the skull, can cause constant ringing in the ears, affect balance and result in deafness. It occurs mainly in people over 50.

headline.main: Bad News for Nerves of Aging Fans of Heavy Metal

docs.abstract: Colin G Edwards, Ohio State University doctoral student, authors research paper that suggests longtime exposure to loud noise, particularly music, increases risk of developing acoustic neuroma, benign nerve tumor; research is published in American Journal of Epidemiology; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Longtime exposure to loud noise may increase the risk of developing a benign nerve tumor called an acoustic neuroma.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the strongest published criticism yet of claims for the sighting of the ivory-billed woodpecker in Arkansas in 2004, an ornithologist who was not involved in the search has called claims for proof of the bird's existence ''faith-based ornithology.'' The ivory bill was, or is, the largest North American woodpecker. It inhabited Southeastern forests that have been heavily logged, and the bird had been thought extinct, although occasional unconfirmed sightings have occurred often since the last confirmed one in the middle of the last century.

headline.main: Ivory Bill Report Is Called 'Faith-Based Ornithology'

docs.abstract: Dr John W Fitzpatrick's report of ivory billed woodpecker sighting, which appeared last year in journal Science, comes under fire from other ornithologists, who say there is no hard evidence that bird is not extinct; Dr Jerome A Jackson, Florida Gulf Coast University ivory bill specialist, holds that video shot of bird is really image of pileated not ivory bill woodpecker; accuses Fitzpatrick of selling ivory bill's existence to promote conservation efforts in Cache River National Wildlife Refuge, where alleged sighting took place (M)
docs.snippet: An new article presents the strongest published criticism yet of claims for the sighting of the ivory-billed woodpecker in Arkansas in 2004.

docs.lead_paragraph: Just out of medical school, I began my intern year by taking care of cancer patients. The work demanded long hours and allowed me into the most intimate aspects of patients' lives. I delivered good news and bad, and spent time with patients' families after they died. I felt like a doctor in every way but one: every night at 7, I punched out on the clock and returned home. No emergency, no matter how dire, allowed me to stay.

headline.main: Interns' Hours Shorter, and That's Good for Patients

docs.abstract: Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education's limits on working hours for interns discussed; Dr David C Leach, council executive director, holds that rule is designed to guarantee that doctors are alert and awake so they can provide safe patient care (M)
docs.snippet: The definition of professionalism for doctors has changed. Today it includes knowing when someone else might take better care of your patient.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: ACCREDITATION COUNCIL FOR GRADUATE MEDICAL EDUCATION

docs.lead_paragraph: Anybody up for a spinal tap? How about a needle through your ribs to siphon fluid from around your lungs? Patients in hospitals and clinics face these sorts of invasive and somewhat risky but potentially lifesaving procedures every day, and in each case, a doctor must decide how much to tell a patient beforehand about the pros, cons and alternatives.
docs.abstract: What constitutes informed consent for medical procedures described; doctors offer their perspective as to best approach for obtaining medical consent; Dr Alan Tait of University Michigan is working on consent form that is easier for parents with low literacy skills to understand; unhurried, candid conversation between doctor and patient is acknowledged by many doctors as essential to informed patient consent; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Candid, unhurried conversations between doctors and patients are too often replaced with a clipboard of legalese and a pen.

docs.lead_paragraph: The encyclopedia of mental disorders known as the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual is built on a principle that many therapists find simplistic: that people's symptoms are the most reliable way to classify their mental troubles. The manual, often called the D.S.M., does not speculate about internal thoughts or unconscious assumptions, which researchers say are all but impossible to scientifically standardize.

headline.main: For Therapy, A New Guide With a Touch Of Personality

docs.abstract: Psychodynamic Diagnostic Manual, new guidebook compiled by psychoanalytic community, provides alternative source for information on mental disorders and their root causes; Diagnostic and Statistical Manual, encyclopedia of mental illness that was built on symptomatic diagnosis of problems and was developed in 1980, is criticized by some psychotherapists as shallow because it disregards complexity of human experience; new book is described as comprehensive, but many experts question its reliability and feasibility for clinical use (M)
docs.snippet: A new diagnostic manual tries to go beyond symptoms to the human complexity at the root of disorders.

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: DIAGNOSTIC AND STATISTICAL MANUAL OF MENTAL DISORDERS (BOOK)

docs.lead_paragraph: Mark Shulman of Woodstock, N.Y., had a scary medical problem: a tumor on his neck. Although a biopsy indicated it was benign, it was growing and had to be removed surgically under general anesthesia. But that turned out to be a much smaller ordeal than the one after Mr. Shulman left the hospital. The doctors thought the unusual growth might have been caused by an infection, so they gave Mr. Shulman large doses of antibiotics. His neck wound was healing nicely, but that's when his troubles really began.

headline.main: Trouble in the Gut, When Antibiotics Work Too Well

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses rise in incidence of Clostridium difficile, spore-forming bacterium that can cause intestinal problems including diarrhea and colitis; infection is often result of antibiotic treatment accompanied by prolonged visit to hospital, where bacterium flourishes; prevention and treatment options discussed; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: A spore-forming, toxin-producing bacterium can flourish in the large intestine when antibiotics kill off the competition.

docs.lead_paragraph: Evening session at the health center, three of us seeing patients in pediatrics. My colleague asked whether I would take a quick look at a boy with a fever and headache. In the exam room, the overhead light was off because it hurt his eyes. He was lying on the table, but he sat up and answered my questions, and he let me look in his throat, and he moved his head around when I asked him to. We excused ourselves, my colleague and I, and went out of the room. We conferred. The boy didn't look good. Pronounced photophobia -- avoidance of light -- and severe headache and fever. And although his neck was not actually stiff, he did indicate some neck pain when we asked him to bend it.

headline.main: The One-in-a-Thousand Illness You Can't Afford to Miss

docs.abstract: Perri Klass Cases column describes diagnosing child's meningitis, infection of membranes that surround spine; fever, headache, stiff neck and extreme sensitivity to light are described as hallmark symptoms of illness, which in most severe cases can lead to death; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Evening session at the health center, three of us seeing patients in pediatrics. My colleague asked whether I would take a quick look at a boy with a fever and headache. In the exam room, the overhead light was off because it hurt his eyes. He was...
